metadata.case_name: Rai Bahadur Jodha Mal Kuthalia v. Rai Bahadur Mohan Singh Oberoi

facts.text: On October 2, 1946, 1st appellant Kuthalia, owner of Sedous Hotel in Lahore, agreed to sell it to 1st respondent Oberoi for Rs. 52,75,000/- with earnest money of Rs. 5,00,000/- advanced and completion date January 20, 1947.

On alleged breach of contract, Civil Suit No. 514/61 of 1946 filed in Senior Sub-Judge Lahore by Oberoi (1st plaintiff) and Associated Hotels of India Ltd. (2nd plaintiff) for recovery of earnest money with interest. Decree in favour of Oberoi for Rs. 5,08,333-5-4 with future interest and costs; suit dismissed for 2nd plaintiff.
Appeal by Kuthalia to High Court of West Pakistan in Lahore; suit dismissed in toto on 24th November, 1949.
Both parties are evacuees under relevant Pakistani laws.

In High Court, stay of execution granted on condition of deposit of Rs. 3,00,000/- on July 16, 1949 and security for balance. Sum deposited by judgment-debtor Kuthalia but decree-holder Oberoi not allowed to withdraw before appeal disposal.
Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance, 1949 promulgated; defines evacuee property vesting in Custodian from March 1, 1947.
After High Court dismissal, Kuthalia applied for refund of deposit on December 1, 1949. Court ordered refund but intimation to Custodian.
Custodian moved High Court on December 20, 1949 to interdict refund as entitled party evacuee; stay granted. Custodian prayed for payment to him as belonging to Kuthalia.
Federal Court of Pakistan restored trial court decree on 21-12-53.
Rehabilitation Commissioner requested High Court on January 4, 1954 to deposit Rs. 3,00,000/- in Treasury as evacuee property.
On January 6, 1954, Kuthalia moved High Court to adjust Rs. 3,00,000/- towards satisfaction of decree, withdraw refund request, dismiss Custodian objections.
Oberoi applied on March 31, 1954 for transfer of deposit to India under Transfer of Evacuee Deposits Act, 1954, asserting no interest of judgment-debtor, deposit in trust for him.
Supreme Court of Pakistan directed transfer of deposit to Custodian for transmission to India, overruling Custodian and Associated Hotels claims.
Deposit remains in Pakistan Treasury despite orders.
Oberoi moved High Court of Punjab at Chandigarh for execution of decree for Rs. 10,79,820/- under s.4(3) Indian Independence Legal Proceedings Order 1947, O.XLV r.15, s.15 CPC.
High Court of Punjab dismissed execution; Supreme Court of India (Gajendragadkar J.) held execution misconceived, must file suit under s.13 CPC.
Oberoi filed suit in India for recovery based on foreign decree; trial court and Delhi High Court decreed in his favour.
Kuthalia filed appeal to Supreme Court by certificate under Art. 133(1)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree of Federal Court of Pakistan vested in Custodian under Pakistan Ordinance 1949, depriving Oberoi of locus standi.
Whether the suit is barred by limitation under Art. 117 Limitation Act, or saved by ss.14/19.
Whether Rs. 3,00,000/- deposit should be adjusted towards the decree on equitable grounds.

petitioner_arguments.text: Decree is evacuee property under Pakistan Ordinance 1949 s.6(1), vested in Custodian from March 1, 1947; Oberoi has no locus standi or cause of action.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1949 ss.2(3), 6(1)

petitioner_arguments.text: Suit on foreign decree barred by 6-year limitation under Art. 117; ss.14/19 Limitation Act do not apply as no acknowledgement or good faith prosecution.
Rs. 3,00,000/- deposited as security for decree, intended for satisfaction; both parties agreed to adjustment; equity requires deduction despite deposit frozen.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Equity; precedents like Chowthmull Manganmull, Sheo Gholam Sahoo

respondent_arguments.text: Decree not treated as evacuee property before Jan 1, 1957; Pakistan Act 1957 s.3(1) excludes it; Custodian never claimed as decree-holder.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Act 1957 s.3(1); CPC s.13

respondent_arguments.text: Execution proceedings prosecuted in good faith after legal advice; jurisdictional defect attracts s.14 Limitation Act exclusion.
Deposit mere security, not automatic satisfaction; no formal adjustment; equity cannot override legal rights.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: No legal basis for equitable inroad without formal order

court_reasoning.text: Decree not evacuee property as Custodian never treated it as such or impleaded; Pakistan 1957 Act s.3(1) prevents treatment post-1957.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custodian did not seek rights qua decree-holder; no demand by Custodian.

court_reasoning.text: Execution proceedings lacked jurisdiction per prior SC ruling; good faith prosecution; s.14 Limitation Act applies to exclude time.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Jurisdictional defect; liberal construction to save claim.

court_reasoning.text: Equity applies interstitially; deposit as security intended for decree satisfaction; both parties agreed post-Federal Court decree; Pakistan govt disregard should not burden judgment-debtor; adjust Rs.3L as of 31-3-1954 when both positions aligned.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Justice requires debtor not pay twice; precedents support equity for deposits as security.

holdings.text: Foreign decree enforceable under CPC s.13; not vested in Custodian.
Time in execution proceedings excluded under Limitation Act s.14; suit not barred.
Rs. 3,00,000/- deposit adjusted towards decree as of 31 March 1954 with interest on balance; entire deposit drawable only by decree-holder.

precedents_cited.case_name: Associated Hotels of India Ltd. v. R.B. Jodha Mal Kuthalia
precedents_cited.relevance: Execution of Pakistani decree misconceived; must file suit under CPC s.13; jurisdictional issue for Limitation s.14

precedents_cited.case_name: Chowthmull Manganmull v. Calcutta Wheat and Seeds Association
precedents_cited.relevance: Deposit into court as security for decree pending appeal belongs to successful party

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheo Gholam Sahoo v. Rahut Hossein
precedents_cited.relevance: Deposit in lieu of security pending appeal not refundable to depositor on confirmation of decree

precedents_cited.case_name: Kothamasu Venkata Subbayya v. Udatha Pitchayya
Ex parte Banner In re Keyworth
precedents_cited.relevance: Money paid into court belongs to party eventually entitled
Deposit to secure fruits of success in appeal

statutes_cited.name: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Ordinance 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting of evacuee property in Custodian; whether decree is evacuee property

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Evacuee Deposits Act 1954 (Pakistan Act VI of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Transfer of court deposits of evacuees to respective countries

statutes_cited.name: Pakistan Administration of Evacuee Property Act 1957 (XII of 1958)
statutes_cited.relevance: Property not treated as evacuee property before Jan 1 1957 not thereafter

statutes_cited.name: Indian Independence (Legal Proceedings) Order 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Execution of certain decrees as if of SC

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Limitation for suit on foreign decree; exclusion and acknowledgement

outcome.summary: Appeal substantially dismissed but allowed in part; suit decree upheld subject to equitable adjustment of Rs. 3,00,000/- deposit as of 31 March 1954 towards decretal amount with interest on balance at 5%; executing court to quantify; proportionate costs in High Court and SC appeals to decree-holder; CA 2248/68 dismissed no costs.
outcome.relief_granted: Decree for balance after adjustment of Rs. 3 lakhs with interest from 31-3-1954; costs in trial court full, appeals proportionate.
outcome.costs: Proportionate costs to decree-holder in Delhi HC and SC appeals; no order in CA 2248/68.

key_quotes.text: All evacuee property shall vest and shall be deemed always to have vested in the Custodian with effect from the first day of March, 1947.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision on vesting under Pakistan Ordinance 1949 s.6(1)

key_quotes.text: Property not to be treated as evacuee property on or after 1st January, 1957.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exclusion under Pakistan 1957 Act s.3(1) saving decree

key_quotes.text: Truth is Law cast in the compassionate mould of justice and equity being one of its facets.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's view on role of equity

key_quotes.text: Equity is not anti-law but a moral dimension of law rather, it is the grace and conscience of living law acting only interstitially.
key_quotes.speaker: court
